title: I've either built from ground-zero or actively participated in the following projects:

data.description:
I was brought onto the team as the third frontend developer for the Monferrato.bike e-commerce project. We were tasked with modernizing and optimizing the webstore for e-bikes, using technologies such as React, remix, tailwind, storybook, cypress, vite, figma, and clickup.

As part of my role, I focused on creating layouts and UI elements, writing unit and e2e tests, and fixing bugs. I worked closely with the QA and Design teams to make sure the website was up to scratch and functioning properly. When we encountered bugs that were difficult to reproduce, I worked with the QA team to get additional information to help us identify and fix the root cause of the problem.

In the latter stages of the project, I mainly focused on debugging the app. When I came across bugs I couldn't fix, I'd request additional information or leave a comment explaining what needed to be done, like asking for a string when the backend was returning an object.

This project was a great opportunity to work with an amazing team of developers, QA, and designers. It also gave me valuable experience in React, remix, tailwind, storybook, cypress, vite, figma, and clickup. The website turned out to be a success, and I'm proud to have contributed to its development.

I worked on the Unagi.media e-learning project as the third frontend developer, along with another developer who joined as the fourth member. The project was built using Vue.js (nuxt.js), PUG, and stylus, and I had the opportunity to work with Node.js (Feathers.js) and Stripe API as well. I reported directly to the CEO and CTO, who were two different individuals.

At the time, I was relatively new to my career and faced numerous difficulties. However, thanks to amazing teamwork, we were able to resolve these issues quickly. Unfortunately, the startup did not succeed in the market, and everyone was laid off. Although I did not have many opportunities to influence the product, there were a few things that made me proud of myself.

First and foremost, I gained valuable mentoring experience by helping the other developer to implement required features through pair programming sessions. Additionally, I once closed 4 (four) Jira issues by deleting a single record from the database that was causing issues after a buggy account deactivation.

Overall, despite the project's unfortunate end, I learned a lot from my experience with Unagi.media. The project taught me the importance of teamwork and communication in software development, as well as the importance of persistence and adaptability in the face of challenges.
